sentence: A fter some rough years, Tile Shop Holdings is seeing its profits soar as the retailer reaps the benefits of an upturn in housing construction and the strategic efforts of a new chief executive.
Tile Shop ( TTS ) stores sell high-end manufactured and natural stone tiles, setting and maintenance materials, and related accessories.
The company had 112 stores in 31 states as of Oct. 27 and it also sells online via its website.
The company serves consumers, contractors, designers and homebuilders.
Tile Shop went through some tough times after going public in 2012, as it opened too many stores in too short a time.
Now, thanks to a game plan crafted by Chris Homeister -- who became CEO on Jan. 1 -- the company is on a roll.
In addition to the use of analytics to determine product selection and other key retail strategies, Homeister's plan revolves around slower new store growth.
In the third quarter, Tile Shop only opened one new store -- in Haltom City, Texas, a Dallas-Fort Worth suburb.
Company officials and analysts agree that rapid store expansion is what derailed the company soon after it went public in 2012.
Piper Jaffray analyst Peter Keith figures that Tile Shop new store growth rose to about a 30% annual rate in 2012 from about a 10% rate during 2010 to 2011.
"The business was pressured as a result of opening a lot of stores at once," Keith told Investor's Business Daily.
"They didn't have the internal staff to support the store growth and the majority of stores added in 2013 and 2014 opened with disappointing revenue."
The massive expansion also created margin pressure and a steady stream of declining profits in 2013 and 2014.
But Tile Shop broke its losing streak in the second quarter as earnings rose 13% vs. a year earlier on a sales gain of 24%.
It hit pay dirt in the third quarter, when profits soared 167% to 8 cents a share, topping views by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for 6 cents a share.
Sales climbed 15.3% to $72.4 million, ahead of forecasts.
The strong sales gain was driven by a hefty 9.7% rise in same-store sales vs. a year earlier, up from a 5.7% gain in the second quarter.
Further, underperforming stores that opened in 2013 and 2014 have turned around.

The stores that opened in 2013 saw sales soar more than 20% in the third quarter -- up from the high teens in the second quarter -- and 2014's stores saw a gain of more than 50%, Chief Financial Officer Kirk Geadelmann said on the quarter's conference call.
Investors cheered the third-quarter results.
Tile Shop shares climbed 14.5% on Oct. 20, the day of the report.
Shares are up 70% since the start of the year.
"Tile Shop has a trifecta of investment themes," Keith said.

"There's a strong industry backdrop, there's a turnaround story in the 2013 and 2014 stores, and it's a retail optimization story (where management applies more analytics in their decision decision making).
The stock is doing extremely well, and all three themes are in place to continue through 2015 and well into 2016."
Analysts see full-year earnings rising 35% to 31 cents a share.
They see a 39% gain in 2016.
New management, Keith adds, is "driving improvements" across the business.
Homeister replaced company founder and former CEO Robert Rucker, who retired.
Homeister, who joined Tile Shop in 2013, had been chief operating officer.
He had previously been general manager and senior vice president ofBest Buy's ( BBY ) entertainment business group.
Homeister has done a lot to revitalize Tile Shop, says Keith.
He notes that Homeister helped "optimize" the retail model by applying more analytical-based decision making.
For example, management has used analytics to better understand the company's core customer and adjust the product mix and service levels to meet the needs of that core customer.
Homeister also has devoted more resources to training employees in the field, Keith adds, and sharpened the company's focus to better serve the professional customer.
The efforts include direct marketing, additional new product offerings and store hosted events, said Homeister on the conference call.
In the third quarter, professional-customer sales growth "outpaced the balance of (the company's business) by a meaningful factor," Homeister added.
Tile Shop competes with companies such as home improvement retail giantsHome Depot ( HD ) andLowe's ( LOW ), though it pales in comparison in terms of sales.
Still, Tile Shop leads the pack in IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Building Products industry group with a 92 IBD Composite Rating out of a possible 99.
Keith says Tile Shop has a "nice value proposition."
It carries over 4,000 products from around the world consisting of ceramic, porcelain, glass and metal tiles, as well as natural stone products including marble and granite.
And Tile Shop's strong performance comes at a time when home remodeling is on the upswing.

"We expect growth in the remodeling sector to be pretty decent in the next couple of years and very much reflect the ongoing housing recovery," Robert Denk, senior economist at the National Association of Home Builders, told IBD.
Denk says remodeling spending is typically driven by new and existing home sales, which are "expected to be good in the next couple of years."
People who are trying to sell their homes spend money to remodel their homes to prepare for resale, says Denk.
And buyers of new homes spend money to put "finishing touches" on their new acquisitions.
House price appreciation plays a role because equity in the home is frequently a source of funding for these projects, says Denk.
"We expect house prices to continue to rise in the next few years, (increasing) at a more sustainable pace," Denk said.
"We're seeing continued home appreciation driving a greater desire for homeowners to take on larger remodeling projects," he said.
"We're also seeing a sharp increase in home equity line originations in 2015, which are being used to fund larger home remodeling projects.
Kitchen and bath remodels are becoming increasingly popular, which is a good dynamic for Tile Shop."
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
